{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3584172,"name":"Erik Boyle","username":"Ekcrbe","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ekcrbe/{size}/221615_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-08T19:29:58.683Z","cooked":"

Are you headed to the Championship and frantically trying to save a pound or two to complete your final upgrades while still making weight? Are you using SDS MK4i or MK4n swerve modules?

We are.

An obvious candidate to us was to swap our steering motors from X60s to X44s. This is the standard configuration on the WCP X2S and X2St and an optional configuration on their full-size X2i and X2t, but it is not possible by default on SDS’s offerings.

So we made these adapter plates to do the job. Our robot uses 2 MK4is and 2 MK4ns, so we have versions for each module. A set of 4 weighs about 0.1 lb.

image806×1055 106 KB

image769×1074 104 KB

A few notes:

  • The 0.159" holes should be tapped to accept the existing #10-32x1.5" motor mounting screws.
  • The MK4n plate works for both type A and type B modules by flipping it over.
  • The plates are designed to be 1/4" aluminum. After removing the 1/16" Kraken spacer, this means the X44 sits 3/16" lower than the X60 did originally. If this is a concern for you and you use MK4is, you could shorten the standoffs, although there is not as easy a way to do so for the MK4ns because of the billet double standoff it utilizes.
  • There are different versions for the two modules because we elected to standardize on 14T steering pinions—this was partly a decision of convenience driven by our particular robot, but I also feel more comfortable with the slightly more conservative ratio on the lower-torque X44—so the MK4i plates hold the motor concentric to the original mounting location while the MK4n plates are shifted by 0.050" to accommodate the change in gear c-c.
  • These last two points in combination mean that the end of the X44 shaft sits off-center inside the shaft clearance hole (not above it) in the top plate of the MK4n module. Be careful not to use too large of a retaining washer on the shaft or it may rub on the inside of the hole.
  • Because of the change in height, assemble the components on the X44 shaft with the 3/16" spacer below the pinion to get proper alignment between the pinion and 50T gear. By default, the steering motor has both spacers above the pinion.

It’s not a groundbreaking advancement, but we thought this was a neat little QoL mod for our existing modules, and we wanted to share it in case anyone else is in a similar place.

cad.onshape.com
